course.subject: LANG
course.name: English for Science I
course.description: An English course for students of the School of Science. The course introduces students to the language and discourse of science and develops their competence in speaking and writing about scientific topics.
course.prerequisites: CORE 1403 OR CORE 1404 OR LANG 1003 (prior to 2022-23)

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: CLE aka CLS
reviews.comment_content: Content consists of the instructor blowing water for every lesson, nothing substantial.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I don't recall Monsieur Dinesh doing any teaching at all.

He also cancelled 2 classes without giving any reasons, and ending the semester 2 weeks early. As you can see he is a very chill and relaxed gentleman.

I would really appreciate it if he had spent more time teaching us how to do his assignments, instead of teaching us absolutely nothing at all then giving me an abysmal score.
reviews.comment_grading:
CLE should official rename themselves to CLS Co. Ltd.

Since I transferred the 6 credits for eng lang, I didn't have to take 1002 and 1003 during Year 1. Therefore, I was not familiar with the absolute shit show that is eng lang courses at UST.

A range is reserved for native speakers who have been speaking English before they left their fathers' testicles. If you are a local like me, even if you are a hardworking straight A's student, you can take your A-range dreams, crush them with a sledgehammer and throw the fragments out the window.

The grade you get in this course is completely unrelated to the effort you put in it. It only depends on your natural speaking skills.
As someone who get 5* in DSE English but only 4 in speaking, I got around 65% for my presentations which is worth around half the course grade in total, which translates to c-range. Before you say I'm an imbecile, I got all A's this semester.

The other reviews that gives this course an A in grading are quite misleading. If you are a local and unfortunately end up in the H stream like me, see if you can drop it and enroll in LANG2010 instead, unless, of course, you are a member of the aforementioned group of people who have attained an exceptional mastery of the English language before their grandfather's balls dropped.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite intense, you have a 3 minute video, a group presentation and a final essay.

I spent 7 hours recording that video. In retrospect, I really shouldn't have spent so much effort.

This course is a waste of your time. You are better for doing the absolute minimum and spending your time on other courses. It would be a much more productive use of your time, since the effort you put into this course is not related to your grade anyway.

reviews.author: Chris Tiffany
reviews.comment_content: Basically, students will learn how to communicate effectively. Prof. Kin will explain many ways to achieve it in different scenarios. But do not expect to learn how to write an academic essay or thesis in this course. It focuses more on effectiveness in communication (such as how to talk effectively to different academic backgrounds of people) but not merely on science.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Kin is very nice.
I remembered he once replied to my email within 15 minutes. When taking his course, you can really feel his passion for teaching. Personally, I am a relatively introverted person and not getting used to speaking publicly. But he is able to calm me down and encourage everyone to share.
The most important thing about him might be that he introduces and explain the assignments thoroughly. Before the assignments, he will bring several examples to class to discuss. During the assignments, we have mandatory consultations and even additional consultations if necessary. After the assignments, self-evaluation is conducted.
Although I do not like lang courses, Prof. Kin is trying his best to make this course interesting and clear.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not bad. For each assignment, students can see the comments and the composition of the scores. It is pretty fair and rational. I put a B here because students cannot achieve good grades if they are not actually paying hard work. In some assignments, especially for the group work and essay, I think Prof. Kin can tell how much you dedicate to the assignments.
reviews.comment_workload:
In terms of the pre-unit quizzes, the workload is very light. Almost none. This is because they are graded based on participation. But it involves group work and essays. Researching and communicating with other people are two of the most time-consuming things for me.
In general, the workload still falls within my expectation. My groupmates are nice so I didn't encounter much trouble.

reviews.author: jsjs
reviews.comment_content:
Course content is not bad.
1: SIPE (Science In Plain English) Oral Presentation
2: Case Study Project on a Natural Disaster

First one is individual and the second is a group project followed by a report written on the same topic but individually.

Personally, researching on natural disasters was not fun.
reviews.comment_teaching: Kin is a fun teacher. He tries to make classes enjoyable and not boring. During classes, he throws jokes to people often. He explains expectations for assignments pretty thoroughly and responds to emails quickly.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is quite good. Makes sense.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 12 Pre-unit quizzes on top of major assignments, but the quizzes take maximum 5 minutes to complete. They're also completion-based.

The projects may take up some time, especially group projects.

reviews.author: Squidgy
reviews.comment_content: I can't visualize what he taught, but somewhat not so boring.
reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.title: Review for new format of course (since Fall 2016-17)
reviews.comment_content:
This is the imaginary 'scenario' which this course is based around:

"The School of Science of the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology has been invited by the United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction (UNISDR) (Links to an external site.) to conduct research and/or experiments to contribute to its project, PreventionWeb.

The research will be presented as case studies, and based on specific hazards identified by UNISDR. Researchers/Authors of these case studies will be invited to present their ideas at UNISDR’s annual Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) Conference in Geneva, Switzerland, which will consist of your Final Group Case Study Report and Final Group Case Study Presentation.

Prior to that, there is a preliminary session taking place in Hong Kong to help you brainstorm and research into different problems and find other researchers/authors with the same/similar interests for the final submission."

Not sure what is the purpose/point of this. You learn a bit about some natural/man-made disasters, but apart from that not much. Provides some writing and presentation skills practice. Overall the course has little relevance to any other courses you have taken or will take as a School of Science student.
reviews.comment_teaching: Toni is excellent. Very clear, enthusiastic, funny, helpful. I really enjoyed every tutorial session with him. Unfortunately I think this was his last term at UST.
reviews.comment_grading:
A preliminary individual case study report: 20%
Identifying, introducing and analysing TWO problems
Justifying their importance and/or urgency
450-550 words for the entire report
Individual work

A final group case study presentation: 30%
Presenting ONE case problem with introduction, analysis, justifications, solutions and recommendations for the problem identified
Presentation time: 15 min
Q&A time: 4 min
Group work

A final group case study report: 25%
As in the preliminary report but focusing on ONE problem
Proposing solutions with justifications recommendations for the problem identified
1500-2000 words
Group work

Vocabulary and Extensive Reading Project (VERP): 15%
Bi-weekly submission of a vocabulary list of minimum 24 self-selected vocabulary items (5%)
450-550-word written reflective report (5%)
5-min verbal progress report with visual aids (5%)
Individual work
Out-of-class work

iPeer: 5%
Peer evaluation of group tasks

Participation: 5%
Attendance at the library workshop on research and referencing skills
Participation in discussion and other tasks
Punctuality
Class attendance
Learning attitude
Preparation work and out-of-class work

Really complex grading involving many assignments, reports, presentations, etc. Need to pay attention to which assignments have the biggest contributions (20-30%) and focus on those.

If you are a native English speaker and have some practice with writing reports and presentations, the grading will be quite easy. Class size is only 18, not sure about the grade distribution (if it is curved or absolute). Grades and mean was not released for all assignments, but I got above mean for at least 50% of the assignments and overall grade A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Too much workload, especially for a 2000-level LANG course. The work is not very difficult, but just takes up too much time. With all the reports, presentations, vocab lists, etc. you have to spend some time almost every day of the term doing some work for this course. This course had more out-of-class work than all of my Science courses in this term combined.
Attendance is also taken and contributes to the participation 5%, and you cannot miss more than 5 tutorials in the term.

reviews.author: Wren
reviews.comment_content: This was my first English LANG class at UST, and I do not know how much it overlaps with LANG 1002&1003. For me, the content was kind of useful. The course included science in plain English, a case study about natural disasters, and a library workshop. Genuinely speaking not tight at all for a one-term course. I mainly learned some presentation skills and knowledge about writing a report.
reviews.comment_teaching: Piotr is a very nice person, flexible, and even casual as a professor. He allowed requested leaves (No matter how ridiculous the reason is) and often dismissed the class earlier. Every class he sounded like he did not feel the need to go through all the formatted class materials. Classes were more like chatting. You can make jokes, feel free to move around, and suggest the pace of study. It would be very interesting if you and your classmates were outgoing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good as a LANG course. Curved together with non-honor classes. The majority would get A range.
Piotr complained about some killers in LANG2010 himself. And he said he would not make this course a burden with bad grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
Some pre-unit quizzes.
A 3min video presentation and a self-evaluation.
A group presentation.
A written report of around 1500 words.
A library workshop and a quiz about it.

reviews.author: ggg_
reviews.title: Piotr is a nice guy
reviews.comment_content:
The whole course can be divided into preparation for two main tasks throughout the whole semester: Science in Plain English (SIPE) Oral Presentation and Case Study Project on a Natural Disaster, where the latter can be further divided into a presentation and a final recommendation report.
Therefore, the contents are mainly techniques for making the SIPE video (e.g. how to engage audience, how to make science more understandable, how to organize a presentation et.), preparing for progress presentation (e.g. making visual aids, presentation etiquette, etc.) and writing a recommendation report (e.g. comparison, visuals, etc.). I actually find the contents quite useful for communicating science, although researching on methods against natural disasters is boring and hard for me. Try to choose a disaster that has a good number of methods would be helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Piotr is very relaxed about teaching. He sometimes tell us that he will make next lesson a "self-directed learning", which means we don't need to come to the class and just need to study the unit by ourselves (which I doubt if anyone did). And he usually dismisses us 20 min earlier than the ending time, which is really nice for a 10:30am~11:50am class. He even seems to not care too much of attendance...
As for each class, he usually just follows the notes of each unit on canvas, supplemented with some extra materials or websites that he suggests us to use. Most of them is indeed useful, like using slidesgo for slides or the instruction on writing a recommendation report. He is also quite humorous, and the class atmosphere is comfortable.
Just as the previous review said, I would say that "Piotr likes and cares about his students". He showed us samples from previous students for almost every assignment. He is willing to give feedback if you ask him to. He even sent us an email after the semester ends to thank us and recognize our effort in the assignments. I don't know whether he sends the same email ever year, but all in all I think he is nice. (Just don't be frightened by his height lol)
reviews.comment_grading:
At first I was kinda shocked by the fluent English that my classmates spoke coz they really spoke like native speakers. But later it turned out that everyone is very nice and hard work pays off.

reviews.author: Yuken
reviews.comment_content: Content is fine, the science may be too easy for ssci students but since the focus is on English, the easy science makes it better to get grades
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is engaging and gives jnstructions as well as answers questions after class fairly quickly
reviews.comment_grading: Depending on the students English level the grading may be a bit harsh
reviews.comment_workload: Substantial work but most are pretty easy. No final or midterm in class so working on the assignments is very important. There are group projects, but only a small portion depends on the groupmates.

reviews.author: Udon98
reviews.comment_content:
There isn't much content that you will learn or require to memorize, which is helpful.

The course also engages you to be more proactive about real-world events and problems, such as natural disasters.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dinesh's teaching style is highly interactive, which is reminiscent of a highschool teaching setting.

He does not expect correct answers, but rather, justifications of opinions raised when talking about particular topics or concepts.

You will also hold in-class discussions, which can be pretty entertaining, since some people can have outrageous opinions that make him laugh.
reviews.comment_grading:
Oral Presentation (SIPE): 15%
Individual case study proposal (500-600 words): 20%
Group presentation (~15 minutes): 30%
- The marks for the group presentation are split that contribute to the overall 30% i.e.
1) Half the marks are from the group performance
2) The other half of the total marks are from your individual performance in the presentation.

Group report (2500 word limit): 25%
iPeer: 5%
Attendance + engagement : 5%

Dinesh can be quite harsh with his grading, so be sure to have your reports and works peer reviewed thoroughly to at least score highly on organization and grammar / diction for the group / individual reports.

For the group tasks, which contributes the most to your grade. Pray that you won't have horrible teammates that will pull you down.
Also, being grouped with people who have good presentation skills will be a huge bonus for your group presentation as well.
reviews.comment_workload:
In exchange for no exams, there is heavy coursework throughout the semester. You shouldn't expect an easy A unless you put a lot of  effort.

The workload becomes especially heavier if you are grouped with free-riders.

reviews.author: cabbi
reviews.comment_content:
the course is centred on 4 tasks (assessments):
1.SIPE speech: present a scientific concept to non-science background audience in plain English
2.Expository writing on a natural disaster that warrants most attention
3.Group project: presentation on methods to deal with a natural disaster
4.Individual report based on the group project
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is passionate about teaching and shares her own stories in a humorous manner. There are lots of in-class discussions. She also opened a "weekly takeaway" window on canvas, where you can share your thoughts with her. the teacher also responds to emails timely and patiently. Feedbacks for assessments are also provided pretty timely.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty fair grading based on the performance of the aforementioned four tasks. An important thing to note is the iPeer evaluation of the group project, which takes up 5 percent of the total grade. The system is closed at 9:00 a.m., which could be easily mistaken as 9 pm or 11:59 pm. Attendance is also taken into account.
reviews.comment_workload: the course is quite tightly-scheduled and the content is pretty packed so there is always something to do...

reviews.author: Yangers
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly focuses on science communication through creating an innovation product. Science fiction stories and popular science topics such as time travel, are included as unit sections to help.

Groups consist of 3-4 people working together to do 2 presentations on a scientific innovation of their creation. Two individual written reports related to the innovation are also included. There are also easy vocab tests and non-graded presentations discussing selected science fiction stories to help with presentation skills.
reviews.comment_teaching: Austin is a very down-to-earth professor and easy to approach. He implements effective ways to help students improve their presentation skills and creates an environment where discussion and constructive feedback are encouraged.
reviews.comment_grading: Overall, this course is relatively easy, so if one works hard enough he/she can easily get an A. Take note that although the written report, presentations and vocab test consist of the majority of the grading scheme, frequent participation in class may help boost the overall grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Compared to other courses, the workload is not that high as there are no exams. The main workload would be simply preparing for the reports and presentations, but that's about it.

reviews.author: butter
reviews.comment_content:
Minimal content: include a few works of science fiction. Will mostly be used to prepare model presentation.
Will be required to give two graded presentations on a new invention of which one will be like a progress report.
Along with each presentation, a report needs to be submitted online.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very nice professor, will tell you about the essence of presentation, and expression without ever making you feel like its being done in an academic way.
reviews.comment_grading: Lenient grading. Just participate in the class, pay attention to what the professor says and incorporate it in your reports and presentations.
reviews.comment_workload: Equivalent to non-existent. The professor makes sure there isn't amount of stress/pressure.
